bibl.title: Despatch from Beverly Y. Payne to Alvey A. Adee, March 27, 1888
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: No 6.
Consulate General of the United States Monrovia, March 24th 1888
Mr B. Y. Payne to the Acting Secretary of State
Subject
Receipt of Despatch No 11 Dip' Ser

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your No 11 Diplomatic Series of January 27th 188 with enclosures relative to the mortality among and the condition of Liberian laborers in the Panama Canal. This despatch was delayed at the Leonard, but immediately after its receipt, I transmitted copies of your enclosures enclosures
enclosures to the Government of Liberia, and I take pleasure in enclosuing to you copy of Secretary Barclay's reply, which I am just in receipt of.
I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient Servant
Beverly Y. Payne
Hon., Alvey A. Adee Act'g Sec'y
Enclosure
Sec'y Barclay's to B. Y. Payne refered to, No 3
No 3
Department of State. Monrovia, March 27th 1888 Liberia W. C. A.

Sir, I have the honor to acknolwedge the receipt of your communication of the 20th inst. with enclosures relative to the mortality among the African laborers employed on the Panama Canal. Menks, and the desire at the Liberian portion of said laborers to return to their homes as soon as possible as is evinced in their letter addressed to the United States Consul General resident at Panama.
In reply, I am to inform you, that this Department Department
Department is in receipt of information that measures are being taken for the speedy return of whatever Liberian Laborers from the Isthmus of Panama to their homes in this Republic.
I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient Servant
Sd E. J. Barclay
Beverly Y. Payne Esq., U.S. act'g Vice Consul Genl Monrovia
